isis.stitle: POWER STEERING GEAR: SHEPPARD M-SERIES - BLEEDING - DUAL STEERING GEARS

svcproc.title: DUAL STEERING GEARS
svcproc.para: Bleeding the dual steering gear system is necessary whenever the system has been repaired or steering fluid has been replaced. Different gear sizes may be used together but the bleeding procedure is the same.

step1.para: Park the vehicle on a clean, dry, solid surface, preferably concrete. Set the parking brake and block the wheels. Place the transmission in neutral. Make sure the engine is OFF.
Jack the vehicle up until the front wheels have cleared the surface. Set the front axle on floor stands.

warning.para: A jack must never be used alone to support vehicle while under-chassis service is being performed. The jack may lower and serious personal injury could result. Always support vehicle with floor stands.

step1.para: Tilt the hood or cab.
Make sure the fluid level in the reservoir is at the full mark on the dipstick.

Remove the drag links from the pitman arms of the master and slave gear. Refer to GROUP 05 - STEERING in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual for the correct procedure to remove the drag link for the vehicle being serviced.
Start the vehicle and allow engine to idle.

Turn the steering wheel to a full left turn and hold until the slave gear moves its full travel. Then turn the steering wheel to a full right turn and hold until the slave moves its full travel. Repeat this procedure three or more times.
Connect the drag link to the master gear. Tighten the attaching nut to:

table.title: Dual Steering Gear Drag Link Nut Torque Chart

caution.para: Do not back off the nut when locating the cotter pin hole.

step1.para: Install a new cotter pin through the ball stud nut, then lock in place.

warning.para: Failure to install a new cotter pin in the ball stud after proper torque could result in an accident, personal injury or death.

step1.para: With the master gear drag link connected, turn the steering wheel to a full left turn and hold until the slave gear pitman arm moves its full travel. Then turn the steering wheel to a full right and hold until the slave gear pitman arm moves its full travel. Repeat this procedure three or more times.
Connect the drag link to the slave gear by turning the steering wheel until the pitman lines up with drag link.

important.para: Do not move the pitman arm by hand during this operation. Air may get in the system.

step1.para: Tighten the attaching nut to:

table.title: Master Gear Drag Link Nut Torque Chart

caution.para: Do not back off the nut when locating the cotter pin hole.

step1.para: Install a new cotter pin through the ball stud nut, then lock in place.

warning.para: Failure to install a new cotter pin in the ball stud after proper torque could result in an accident, personal injury or death.

step1.para: Steer the vehicle full left to full right several more times.
Locate the bleeder screw in the master gear located in the plug on the sector shaft bore ( Figure 32).
Use an AlIen wrench to open the bleeder screw until a non-aerated fluid flows from the bleed screw.

note.para: Do not turn the steering wheel with the bleeder open.

step1.para: Repeat the procedure on the slave gear if an M-Series slave is used.
Check the fluid level in the power steering reservoir and fill if necessary.
Shut the vehicle off.
Lower the hood or cab.
Raise the vehicle and remove the floor stands. Lower the vehicle until the tires contact the surface.
